commander.name: Major-General Noel Beresford-Peirse
commander.previous_service: Commander of Artillery, 4th Indian Division (1939-1940). Promoted to divisional command August 1940.

command.headquarters_location: Egypt (Western Desert, Operation Compass sector Dec 9-11; transferring to Sudan from Dec 12)

QF 25-pounder Mk I.organization: Three field regiments (1st, 25th, 31st Field Regiments RA - 24 guns each)

3-inch Mortar.organization: Brigade and battalion mortars (includes 16th Brigade through 14 December)

subordinate_units.composition: 1st Royal Fusiliers, 3/1st Punjab Regiment, 4/6th Rajputana Rifles
subordinate_units.operations: Attacked Tummar positions during Operation Compass

subordinate_units.composition: 1/4th Essex Regiment, 3/2nd Punjab Regiment, 1/6th Rajputana Rifles
subordinate_units.operations: Departed Egypt for Sudan 28 December 1940 (first element to transfer)

subordinate_units.composition: 1/6th Rajputana Rifles, 2nd Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders, 4/7th Rajput Regiment
subordinate_units.operations: Destroyed Italian Maletti Group at Nibeiwa Camp (9 December 1940) with 7th RTR support. Departed for Sudan 1 January 1941.

subordinate_units.composition: British infantry brigade. Participated in Operation Compass (9-11 Dec). Detached 14 December 1940.
subordinate_units.operations: Participated in Operation Compass battles. Detached 14 December after Sidi Barrani victory.

subordinate_units.composition: 1st Field Regiment RA, 25th Field Regiment RA, 31st Field Regiment RA (72x 25-pdr total), one anti-tank regiment (48x 2-pdr)
subordinate_units.operations: Provided fire support during Operation Compass

subordinate_units.composition: Three field companies, one field park company

tactical_doctrine.role: Main infantry assault force for Operation Compass (9-11 December 1940). Executed breakthrough attacks on Italian fortified camps at Sidi Barrani. After victory, division rapidly transferred to Sudan (12 Dec onwards) for East African Campaign.
special_capabilities: Combat-proven in Operation Compass offensive operations
Successful combined arms coordination (infantry-tank cooperation with 7th RTR)
Rapid strategic redeployment capability (Western Desert to Sudan in 16 days)
Mixed British and Indian battalions providing tactical flexibility
Reinforced with British 16th Infantry Brigade through 14 December
tactical_innovations: Night approach march followed by dawn assault (Nibeiwa attack)
Close infantry-tank cooperation with Matilda II tanks (7th RTR)
Rapid exploitation after breakthrough (Nibeiwa to Tummar same day)
known_issues: No organic tank support - dependent on British armored units
Limited anti-aircraft defenses against Italian air attacks
Rapid redeployment to Sudan reduced time for rest after combat
16th Brigade detached immediately after Operation Compass (14 Dec)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division executed first major British offensive in Western Desert with complete success. Destroyed Italian Maletti Group at Nibeiwa and captured multiple fortified camps. Demonstrated effective desert warfare doctrine combining speed, surprise, and combined arms coordination.

validation.data_quality_notes: Q4 1940 represents critical transition quarter for 4th Indian Division. Division participated in Operation Compass (9-11 December 1940) as main infantry assault force under Western Desert Force command. 11th Indian Infantry Brigade's destruction of Italian Maletti Group at Nibeiwa Camp confirmed from multiple sources. 16th British Infantry Brigade attachment confirmed through 14 December 1940 (detached immediately after Operation Compass). Sudan transfer timing well-documented: disengagement began 12 December, 7th Brigade embarked 28 December, 11th Brigade departed 1 January 1941, 5th Brigade transferred by rail/Nile steamer, entire division concentrated in Sudan by end of January 1941. Division maintained same equipment levels as Q3 (no time for refit between October readiness and December offensive). Artillery composition confirmed as three field regiments (1st, 25th, 31st Field Regiments RA) with 72x 25-pounders total, plus divisional anti-tank regiment with 48x 2-pounders. Personnel strength maintained at 17,800 through 14 December due to 16th Brigade attachment. Supply status improved from Q3 due to pre-offensive preparations. Location transitioned from Egypt (Western Desert) to Sudan within Q4. Commander Beresford-Peirse continued from Q3 appointment. Confidence increased to 82% due to well-documented Operation Compass participation and multiple source confirmation of key dates and actions.
